d16afa0ae7c.description: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales. Part of WIRED Media Group.
d16afa0ae7c.name: Backchannel
d16afa0ae7c.shortDescription: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales.

paragraphs.text: You can pat yourself on the back clicking around, looking for a cheap hotel room or a great airfare. But it might be better to resort to an old technology: Just pick up the phone and call the front desk.
paragraphs.name: 5a41

paragraphs.text: There are already signs that computer and smartphone users are wizening up. Sarah Hughes, a cofounder of travel industry consulting firm Fiz, has reported that research shows that “the majority of users now prefer to book directly via airlines and hotels rather than rely on online travel agencies….What does this tell us? That consumers are more interested in travel brands than they are in having information pre-filtered according to a narrow set of perceived needs.”
paragraphs.name: 965b

paragraphs.text: This time, the cheapest fare wasn’t that cheap: It was for an Alitalia flight that made two stops, through Milan and Rome, for $2,050. Surprised at the high quote, he decided to call Alitalia. Immediately, the airline offered a $1,550 flight with only one stop in Rome. It was cheaper. It would get there faster. They even offered him a discounted car rental.
paragraphs.name: c33e

paragraphs.text: Technology aided in this inevitable disruption, and ultimately helped create some of the pricing chaos we see today. As the internet became the first stop for travel shopping, we started searching for bargains via keystroke commands. We stopped talking to hotel clerks, rental car agents, and airline reservation agents, and we boasted to our friends about our low-cost vacations to Lake Como.
paragraphs.name: fd6f

paragraphs.text: You can pat yourself on the back clicking around, looking for a cheap hotel room or a great airfare. But it might be better to resort to an old technology: Just pick up the phone and call the front desk.
paragraphs.name: 5a41
5a41
paragraphs.text: You can pat yourself on the back clicking around, looking for a cheap hotel room or a great airfare. But it might be better to resort to an old technology: Just pick up the phone and call the front desk.

Great article! I recently called a hotel I was travelling to on business to get their quote and then researched online to see if I could find a better fare. In my case, the online aggregator was able to cut me a deal that the hotel did not. It’s interesting to see that I might need to do this more often now to get the best rate.
paragraphs.name: 399a

paragraphs.text: Really informative stuff. What I’ve done for about the last 7 or 8 years is use the aggregators to get a sense of the landscape for hotels or flights. When I find something that looks good, I go to the company site first to see if I can get the same or better deal. As the article states, many times the better deal is with the brand directly.
paragraphs.name: 2a6f

61c167e5798b.title: All this is giving an opportunity for the small players on the market to grab some users.

paragraphs.text: All this is giving an opportunity for the small players on the market to grab some users. I use speedifly.com and am quite happy with the curated deals going up there and the business model gimmick they have.
paragraphs.name: d710

paragraphs.text: True and is applicable everywhere. In India, I’ve seen the exact same thing taking place with Jet Airways.
paragraphs.name: 63ef

2a38c37b57df.title: Funny how the internet that was supposed to change the world and make things faster and less…

paragraphs.text: Funny how the internet that was supposed to change the world and make things faster and less expensive has actually become the opposite. I live in California and Uber has made getting a taxi cheaper and faster but now Jerry Brown wants to raise taxes on gas again to an additional .12 a gallon on top of some of the most expensive gas in the country…
paragraphs.name: d008

88c1fcbfa6c.title: I just tried downloading the Hilton app and doing a local search.

paragraphs.text: I just tried downloading the Hilton app and doing a local search. It found my local Hilton but claimed “no rooms are available”.
paragraphs.name: 661a

paragraphs.text: I find that entirely impossible to believe, so uninstalled the app. Waste of space.

virtuals.subtitle: I find that entirely impossible to believe, so uninstalled the app. Waste of space.

content.subtitle: I find that entirely impossible to believe, so uninstalled the app. Waste of space.

8469f96630a4.title: When flying, use an aggregator to find the best flights (fewer/no stops, better flight times…

paragraphs.text: When flying, use an aggregator to find the best flights (fewer/no stops, better flight times, fastest connections) and then identify the AIRLINE(s). Then go to that airline’s website. Boom. I just saved you a ton of money.
paragraphs.name: 62ba

aef527d39bb6.title: This article expounded the flaws in booking systems superbly.

paragraphs.text: This article expounded the flaws in booking systems superbly. Imagine my shock when I offered to buy my dad a flight ticket (so that he wouldn’t have to go through this ordeal process) and he got it from the flight desk at a price much cheaper than what I was going to pay.
Next time pickup the damn phone and book yourself ☺
paragraphs.name: eb13

virtuals.subtitle: Next time pickup the damn phone and book yourself ☺

content.subtitle: Next time pickup the damn phone and book yourself ☺

abf93bdcec.title: I work in the accommodation industry.

paragraphs.text: I work in the accommodation industry. It’s a joy to see accommodation providers yearning for more direct bookings.
paragraphs.name: 24e2

paragraphs.text: Exorbitant commission. That’s one of the major driving forces.
paragraphs.name: cf20

paragraphs.text: It makes my toes tingle to know that there is a battle, albeit a tiny one.
paragraphs.name: ecb8

virtuals.subtitle: Exorbitant commission. That’s one of the major driving forces.

content.subtitle: Exorbitant commission. That’s one of the major driving forces.

paragraphs.text: Excellent article and very informative. In the last year I had begun to suspect I wasn’t getting the best rates from these sites anymore. Thank you for the confirmation.
paragraphs.name: 7a6f

d91bb68d6bc1.title: I guess at some point we will have AIs that will find the best deal contacting directly airlines…

paragraphs.text: I guess at some point we will have AIs that will find the best deal contacting directly airlines, hotels and so on, doing (for a fraction of the price) exactly what human travel agents were doing until a couple of decades ago.
paragraphs.name: 18ea

paragraphs.text: BTW, I stopped using OTA and aggregator years ago. Even when they offer a better deal, it is never…
paragraphs.name: f0f3

virtuals.subtitle: BTW, I stopped using OTA and aggregator years ago. Even when they offer a better deal, it is never more than 5–10% less than the what you…

content.subtitle: BTW, I stopped using OTA and aggregator years ago. Even when they offer a better deal, it is never more than 5–10% less than the what you…

88096838a871.title: Or use OTAs to find accommodation establishments’ names, google them and visit their websites.

paragraphs.text: Or use OTAs to find accommodation establishments’ names, google them and visit their websites. My wife does it that way. We despise OTAs.
paragraphs.name: 682e

e1aaf79c1287.title: The other problem is that the true cost of hotels and airlines are now “below the line”.

paragraphs.text: The other problem is that the true cost of hotels and airlines are now “below the line”. So you can’t price compare.
paragraphs.name: 4bb4

paragraphs.text: For hotels, they tack on their compulsory “resort fees”. But that fee isn’t part of the price advertised. Plus they charge extra for parking. Extra for internet. Plus local hotel/bed taxes that some cities…
paragraphs.name: 6fc0

virtuals.subtitle: For hotels, they tack on their compulsory “resort fees”. But that fee isn’t part of the price advertised. Plus they charge extra for…

content.subtitle: For hotels, they tack on their compulsory “resort fees”. But that fee isn’t part of the price advertised. Plus they charge extra for…

paragraphs.text: Good article. Well written. After using Expedia one time too many, we’re done with them. Left us stranded in an airport on a Saturday night. Flight cancelled due to snow, and airlines (Jetblue and Aer Lingus) wouldn’t help us with rerouting because they said Expedia had to do it. Expedia said they couldn’t help; the supervisor I spoke to even lied…
paragraphs.name: f1d4

750e681fa395.title: Interesting article, thank you for posting.

paragraphs.text: Interesting article, thank you for posting. I happen to work for an OTA and can say that OTAs do have some of the best deals out there, but we are limited by the inventory that our air, hotel and rental partners provide e us. Many partners are trying to enter the market themselves, by going straight to Google for example, and selling their inventory…
paragraphs.name: bc97

a1a86739861.title: Maybe it should also tell you that we’re sick off all the extra steps and hype that must be endured…

paragraphs.text: Maybe it should also tell you that we’re sick off all the extra steps and hype that must be endured when using those sites. And hey, what do you know? It’s actually cheaper, as well as easier, booking right at the source.
paragraphs.name: 0b6d

fed278efeb1a.title: I’ve always used a travel site (usually WebJet, being relatively popular here in Australia) to find…

paragraphs.text: I’ve always used a travel site (usually WebJet, being relatively popular here in Australia) to find the provider with the lowest price, and then make the booking via the provider’s own site rather than through the travel site to avoid paying the travel site’s commission (WebJet seems to take $10-$20 for domestic flights) and get any perks like…
paragraphs.name: 8d17

virtuals.subtitle: I honestly thought this is how everyone does it, who actually books through the travel sites?

content.subtitle: I honestly thought this is how everyone does it, who actually books through the travel sites?

4b81bfdc2b09.title: One thing that gets missed by many, if you book a trip thru an internet site and you have issues…

paragraphs.text: One thing that gets missed by many, if you book a trip thru an internet site and you have issues, you have to deal with that site and not the airline/hotel directly, the airline/hotel may even be very unwilling to help due to profit structure.
paragraphs.name: cfdd

paragraphs.text: The other issue is many of the internet sites have made a number of bad business decisions.
paragraphs.name: 05b6

virtuals.subtitle: The other issue is many of the internet sites have made a number of bad business decisions.

content.subtitle: The other issue is many of the internet sites have made a number of bad business decisions.

ca5e1c927b3e.title: Hi, Doug. I enjoyed your article. Just a couple of clarifications:

paragraphs.text: Hi, Doug. I enjoyed your article. Just a couple of clarifications:
paragraphs.name: 9bd4

paragraphs.text: Expedia is not an aggregator/meta-search, it is an OTA itself. Meta-search engines are sites like skyscanner, hipmunk, trivago and kayak to mention some.
paragraphs.name: 07a8

paragraphs.text: At the beginning of the article you make the distinction between OTAs and meta…
paragraphs.name: 0b1e

paragraphs.name: 77b8

paragraphs.text: This is good. Thank you.
I travel a lot and have been suspicious about why I find such a variety of prices on the products I want. I’ve taken to guessing and telling Priceline how much I’ll pay. It usually works.
paragraphs.name: ac49

paragraphs.text: The other source that cuts through a lot of the nonsense, btw, is surprisingly intuitive: Google.

85a25bc4dbcb.title: A lot of travel-related businesses are dishonest with their customers, hiding secret fees and stuff…

paragraphs.text: A lot of travel-related businesses are dishonest with their customers, hiding secret fees and stuff.
paragraphs.name: 4b74

paragraphs.text: It’s a shame that honesty isn’t the rule of such an important industry.
Anyway, thanks for that informative story, we’re gonna share it with our community !
paragraphs.name: bb73

979e8bbf47a8.title: Why Bargain Travel Sites May No Longer Be Bargains

paragraphs.text: Why Bargain Travel Sites May No Longer Be Bargains
paragraphs.name: 550b

paragraphs.text: Aggregators like Expedia have made us lazy — and we may be missing out on the best deals.
paragraphs.name: b7d9

virtuals.subtitle: Aggregators like Expedia have made us lazy — and we may be missing out on the best deals.

content.subtitle: Aggregators like Expedia have made us lazy — and we may be missing out on the best deals.

paragraphs.text: Great article. One question I do have though is where would someone go if they want a bundle package, such as a flight+hotel package. Booking through a third party website still seems the best way to go for this IMO.
paragraphs.name: f200
